Curt Sampson wrote:

> On Sat, 10 Jul 2004, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > ....then write one test called "testDatabaseConnection()". If that
> > fails, then the rest is self-evident.
>
> Right. But the problem is finding that one important failure in the list
> of 250 failures that you got from your test run.

If the database connection fails that often, perhaps it is necessary to 
solve that particular problem. In an old test-setup where we used 
mainframe transactions from a RS6000 websphere setup, the mainframe 
transaction we called would fail every 25/30 transactions. When we 
*finally* reported this to the mainframe guys, they found a bug in their 
software that caused this. From then on, we were on the right track to 
100% test success.

We also created from flipover charts a progression of our testresults. 
Each time the mainframe connection failed, our score dropped to 25% 
success or so. If this is a pattern for more than 2 weeks, something has 
to be done.

If the database is giving you so much trouble, and you can't fix the 
setup because the database is out of your reach, setup a local database, 
or use HSQL as development database.

The tests tell what is wrong, and in my opinion it is not JUnit. ;-)

Martijn Dashorst
